content: What is the truth value of the statement "There exists an x such that P(x)" under the condition that the set of x is non-empty and P(x) is a predicate that returns a boolean value?

The truth value of the statement "There exists an x such that P(x)" depends on whether there is at least one element in the set of x for which the predicate P(x) evaluates to true. Given that the set of x is non-empty, if there is at least one element in this set that makes P(x) true, then the statement is true. Otherwise, if P(x) is false for every element in the set, the statement is false. In formal logic, this is an existential quantification, typically denoted by the symbol ∃.
